postsData.content:
The # 1 change you need to make to your outbound emails in 2025 if you expect your prospects to reply. 



Make your emails shorter.

Make your LinkedIn messages EVEN shorter.


Ô∏è 3 reasons why this is a MUST if you expect to
to your prospect's attention:


1. Optimize for mobile

Depending on who you ask, the optimal length of a cold outbound sales email is 16-130 words.

Regardless of the source, the consensus is shorter emails get better results.

One reason is that shorter emails can be read on a mobile device without having to scroll.

If your prospect can read your CTA without having to scroll you are significantly more likely to get a reply.


2. Reduce mental load

Shorter emails, especially those that utilize spacing between sentences get higher reply rates.

Short, simple sentences are easier for prospects to scan and quickly absorb.

By writing short, simple emails with ample spacing, you're making it easier for your prospect to engage with your email.


3. Make a point that matters TO THEM

Shorter emails force you to get to the point!

Write straightforward emails that focus on what matters to your prospect (HINT: eliminate as much I, We, Our language as you can) and you'll see an increase in your reply rates within the week.


 What word or character count do you aim for when writing sales emails?

$42,000 was my first year SDR salary
I made more this month (10yrs later)‚Ä¶
b/c of 2 consistent attitudes since 2015

1) Treat my job like a paid MBA.

2) Work for the company, not the paycheck.

Reminds me of this story Zig tells

‚ÄúSeveral years ago on an extremely hot day, a crew of men were working on the road bed of the railroad when they were interrupted by a slow moving train.

The train ground to a stop and a window in the last car‚Äî which incidentally was custom made and air conditioned‚Äîwas raised.

A booming, friendly voice called out, ‚ÄúDave, is that you?‚Äù Dave Anderson, the crew chief called back, ‚ÄúSure is, Jim, and it‚Äôs really good to see you.‚Äù

With that pleasant exchange, Dave Anderson was invited to join Jim Murphy, the president of the railroad, for a visit.

For over an hour the men exchanged pleasantries and then shook hands warmly as the train pulled out.

Dave Anderson‚Äôs crew immediately surrounded him and expressed astonishment that he knew Jim Murphy, the president of the railroad, as a personal friend.

Dave then explained that twenty-three years earlier he and Jim Murphy had started work at the railroad on the same day.

One of the men, half jokingly and half seriously, asked Dave why he was still working out in the hot sun and Jim Murphy had gotten to be president.

Rather wistfully, Dave explained, ‚ÄúTwenty-three years ago I went to work for $1.75 an hour and Jim Murphy went to work for the railroad.‚Äù

- Zig Ziglar, See You at the Top


There aren‚Äôt ‚Äúsecrets‚Äù to success

There are those who choose to do what they‚Äôre paid to do, and that‚Äôs all.

And others who go to work for the railroad.

postsData.content:
Most sales kickoffs are a waste of time.


If they aren't done right.

If they're packed with overhyped fluff, endless slideshows and an overload of product features - sales reps will forget everything the second they walk out of the room. And can you even blame them?

Your SKO's should be focused on setting your teams up to close more deals and driving revenue.

Here‚Äôs how to make sure you get yours right on the money...

1Ô∏è‚É£ Kill the fluff and focus on strategy.

Your SKO is a game plan. If you‚Äôre not giving sales reps clarity on how to win in today's market, what is even the point? Here's what you should be focusing on:

 What‚Äôs the revenue gap this year?
 What specific behaviours do reps need to adopt to close it?
 How are leadership, sales, marketing, ops, customer success, and enablement going to make it happen together?

2Ô∏è‚É£ Align EVERYONE - not just sales.

If you‚Äôre only talking to sales, you‚Äôre already behind. Sales doesn‚Äôt succeed alone. It takes an entire team, and everyone working together.

 Get marketing, sales, customer success and ops in the same room and give everyone a voice.

 Fix the bottlenecks that slow deals down - work together to solve problems, instead of playing the blame game.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Don‚Äôt let the SKO end when the event does.

Don‚Äôt let the motivation and learning stop the moment the SKO is over. Make sure you continue to:

 Reinforce key takeaways with follow-ups, coaching, and real-time feedback.

 Track your results. Tie your SKO activities directly to win rates, pipeline growth, and shorter sales cycles.

Here‚Äôs the bottom line: Reps should leave your SKO knowing exactly how they‚Äôre going to hit their number this year - and what you‚Äôre doing to help them get there. If they don't, you risk your SKO being branded as "a waste of time".

What‚Äôs the best thing you‚Äôve seen at an SKO? Let‚Äôs hear it

postsData.content:
Only you can prevent "I hope you're well" emails. 

Why are people so emotionally attached to this opener?

When I train sales teams, I hear the same reasons every time:

- It‚Äôs polite
- It's a cultural thing
- I don‚Äôt want to seem rude
- It softens the intrusion of a cold email

I get it.

Writing a cold email can feel uncomfortable. You‚Äôre reaching out to someone you don‚Äôt know, hoping for a response.

Adding ‚ÄúI hope this finds you well‚Äù might *feel* like the safer, friendlier choice.


Ô∏è But here‚Äôs the reality:

Your prospects don‚Äôt find this phrase warm or thoughtful.

They see it as filler.

It triggers their mental spam filters.

In a world of overflowing inboxes, filler is the first thing to get ignored.


Ô∏è Here‚Äôs the truth:

You don‚Äôt need an empty opener to prove you‚Äôre kind or respectful.

The real way to make a cold email feel less intrusive is to focus on preview text.

Preview text is the first 10(ish) words of your email INCLUDING the subject line.

It‚Äôs your first impression, your chance to stand out, and what decides whether your email gets opened, or skipped.

If your preview text starts with ‚ÄúI hope this finds you well,‚Äù you‚Äôve wasted that moment.


 Cold emails don‚Äôt have to feel intrusive.

When you make every word count - starting with preview text - you earn the attention you need to start a conversation.

What is one common email practice you want to see die in 2025?

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Focusing on meaningful openers can truly transform cold emails. Lets elevate our communication and cut out the filler!

: Believe it or not, cold-calling the right people at the right time with the right message is making a massive impact. Again You need the skills to do it, and it‚Äôs working wonders. use an Agency like

Give them all the information they need, and when they need it make it easy to find it and progress again dont make things hard for your champion or potential customers to make the deal.

-95% of professionals believe that face-to-face meetings are essential for long-term business relationships.

-Digital sales rooms can accelerate deal cycles by up to 50% by providing a centralized space for all sales-related interactions and documents.

49% of buyers prefer that initial contact be made via cold call.

57% of C-level executives and VPs list cold calling as their preferred method of being contacted.

 Celebrate Your Uniqueness (Don't be a Copycat): That quirky, distinct perspective of yours? It's your superpower. Let it radiate in all you do because with all the copycats out there, the world craves originality now more than ever!

 Innovate Fearlessly (Stretch beyond the Box): Break the chains of the conventional and shake up the status quo. Innovation isn't just an idea; it‚Äôs a lifestyle that propels you beyond the ordinary and into the extraordinary!

postsData.content:
One question I get asked a lot is, ‚ÄúWhat does an AI-powered computer actually do?‚Äù.

Maybe it‚Äôs something you‚Äôve wondered about too? Let me help‚Ä¶

AI, or artificial intelligence, is a computer‚Äôs ability to mimic human intelligence by doing things like learning patterns, understanding speech, or even creating content.

AI-powered computers contain special processors and algorithms that make them faster and smarter at handling these tasks.

Think of it like this: Traditional PCs rely on you to tell them exactly what to do, step by step. AI PCs, on the other hand, can learn from how you work and make smart decisions by themselves to help you out. For example, they can summarize reports, draft emails, schedule meetings, or even translate conversations during video calls.

For businesses, AI PCs are changing the game. They can save you time by handling repetitive tasks, boost productivity with personalized workflows, and even increase security by monitoring for unusual behavior and adapting to new threats.

And the best part?

With AI built into the computer itself, sensitive data stays local, improving privacy and security for your business.

Does the idea of using AI-powered PCs in your business excite you? Or does it seem like too much tech to handle?
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! AI-powered PCs can revolutionize efficiency and security. Excited to see how businesses will leverage this tech! üöÄ

postsData.content:
I had a wonderful week at the World Economic Forum this week. But except in a few places, the spirit of Davos is fading. 

The Davos week is one I look forward to each year, as it is the moment to reconnect with like-minded people and inspire each other on issues like climate action.

But this year, while I personally had my best experience ever, leading events on nature and business, climate action, and brain health, my overall assessment is that Davos has become Trump‚Äôs Davos, and that the spirit of Davos is fading.

I say Davos, because I‚Äôve been part of the WEF for long enough to know this isn‚Äôt intentional on behalf of the organization that convenes global business and government leaders here.

At WEF, the spirit to improve the state of the world remains alive and well.

, the CEO of, told me, for example, that he attended a WEF session with business leaders and Volodymyr Zelenskyy, to discuss how business could help reconstruct Ukraine.

He also went to a meeting of the CEO Climate Alliance, where dozens of CEOs recommitted their companies to Paris aligned climate targets, just as so many US businesses and the new US administration are pulling out.

And some side-events remain as trailblazing as ever, bringing stakeholders together on issues from nature to health. That was the Davos bubble I was and am part of, and that energizes me so much.

But as a journalist, I did venture outside of that bubble too, and what I saw there was sobering. The mainstream of Davos has shifted away from the stakeholder origin of WEF.

I met with dozens of mostly US business leaders who said they were in Davos for one reason, and one reason only: to do business.

Longtime skeptics and critics of Davos will probably shrug at this notion. It‚Äôs what Davos has been known for for many years ‚Äî it‚Äôs a place for the global business elite to meet each other and enrich themselves, they would say.

But that‚Äôs not how I saw Davos over the years. For attending business leaders, the split was often something like 80-20: 80% business meetings, 20% working on WEF agenda.

Now, however, even that 20% is fast disappearing, at least for US participants. Their political climate is such that stakeholder capitalism, sustainability, and globalism are absolute faux-pas. The business of business is business, once again.

In some discussions I led, when ideas around global collaboration, nature, or social responsibility were expressed, the general reaction was one of utter disinterest, if not dismissal.

And that, I believe, is because the American side of Davos has overnight become Trump‚Äôs Davos. The singular focus of many US business leaders is to increase their profits and mind their own business. Working on a global agenda, or with other stakeholders, is a distraction, and a risk.

I‚Äôm as energized as ever returning from Davos. But the idea that Davos is a place for stakeholderism and globalism, is now minoritarian. The Davos spirit is fading.

Engage with others‚Äô posts by liking, commenting, and sharing. Genuine interaction fosters reciprocity and increases visibility.

Unclear Branding:
Update your headline and summary to reflect what you do and how you provide value. Ensure your profile picture and background align with your brand.

Lack of Niche Content:
Start focusing on your niche and creating content around it. This positions you as an expert, making it easier to connect with your target audience.

Inconsistent Posting:
Create a posting schedule and stick to it. Consistency is key to staying relevant and visible to your audience.
Good points!
Sometimes, less is more. Emphasize clarity over complexity. Especially in content!
Focusing on 100% value is what changes the game!
Every time, Jake.

postsData.content:
The Age of AI: Themes from the World Economic Forum Davos 2025

1Ô∏è‚É£ The Rise of AI Agents

‚ÄúToday‚Äôs CEOs are the last to manage an all-human workforce.‚Äù The excitement around AI agents was palpable, with OpenAI‚Äôs Operator leading the charge. While these systems remain in a phase of experimentation, the potential is clear‚ÄîAI agents are poised to transform workflows, enhance decision-making, and redefine industries. This isn‚Äôt just a moment of hype; it‚Äôs the dawn of a new operational paradigm.

2Ô∏è‚É£ US vs. China: The AI Arms Race

China‚Äôs deployment of millions of super-smart AI agents sparked profound discussions on how AI could reshape power dynamics. ‚ÄúThe power of dictatorships has traditionally been constrained by human limitations. AI removes that constraint.‚Äù

At the same time, the rise of open-source AI models like DeepSeek R1 is challenging the dominance of proprietary systems. With its impressive performance and low cost, DeepSeek R1 embodies the promise of democratized AI‚Äîbut also raises questions of trust. Can businesses and governments rely on open-source AI for critical operations? This tension highlights the growing geopolitical stakes of AI innovation.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Human Evolution and the Age of FOBO

FOBO‚ÄîFear of Becoming Obsolete‚Äîwas a recurring theme at Davos. ‚ÄúTools are becoming better than humans at almost every task.‚Äù

The rapid evolution of AI is forcing humanity to rethink not just work but purpose & identity. How do we adapt to a future where AI outpaces human cognitive abilities? Optimists see this as an unparalleled opportunity‚Äîthose who embrace change and prioritize AI literacy will lead in the age of intelligence.

4Ô∏è‚É£ AI Governance: The Key to Unlocking AI‚Äôs Potential

Governance was a central focus this year, and for good reason: without it, the full promise of AI cannot be realized. Trust is the foundation of adoption, and governance frameworks are critical to ensuring AI systems like DeepSeek R1‚Äîopen-source yet powerful‚Äîare reliable, secure, and aligned with societal values.

Leaders at Davos recognized that governance is an enabler of innovation.

5Ô∏è‚É£ AI Investment Amid Uncertainty

Despite economic volatility, AI investment continues to accelerate. The excitement around AI agents, powerful open-source models, and generative capabilities is driving a renewed wave of optimism.
However, overlapping hype cycles demand careful navigation. Investors and businesses must focus on applications that align with governance and trust principles to scale AI responsibly.

Thanks to all the AI tools who joined me at Davos - helped take notes, summarize key themes , follow up fast & efficiently on all my to-dos  

Davos 2025 made one thing clear: AI‚Äôs future depends on our ability to evolve alongside it‚Äîresponsibly and with Governance and trust as our foundation. cc

postsData.content:
One problem I commonly see with AI:

Starting with complex use cases and underestimating the effort it takes to see quality results.

When building AI solutions, it‚Äôs easy to fall into this trap:

‚Üí Tackling multiple use cases
‚Üí Using diverse datasets
‚Üí Optimizing for different roles

This results in underwhelming results. Output quality isn't there. Pilots stall or stop, even if the use case seems feasible for AI to tackle.

Here‚Äôs the advice I gave a team recently:

Optimize for quality, not scale (at least at first).

Here‚Äôs the approach:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Start with a smaller scope to validate the solution.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Focus on output quality‚Äîensure it works well before expanding.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Once you have clear results, scale gradually.

This means that you'll need to compromise. Instead of trying to achieve all possible use cases that AI "could" achieve. Optimize for a specific use case (i.e. data source or data type), then expand from there.

The key with AI isn‚Äôt to boil the ocean.

Don‚Äôt assume because ‚Äúit‚Äôs AI,‚Äù it will:
„ÉªWork through the complexity on its own
„ÉªUnderstand context without guidance
„ÉªHandle large and diverse data sets without optimizations

Start small.
Optimize for quality.
Scale gradually.

Ô∏è Repost.
Follow for more.

comments.commentText: Your point about starting small and optimizing for quality resonates strongly with my experience in AI adoption. Focusing on solving specific challenges, rather than tackling everything at once, ensures impactful outcomes and smoother scalability. AI thrives when it augments existing processes with clear purpose and precision.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Focusing on quality over scale is crucial for successful AI implementation. Starting small can lead to more impactful results!
